text: Hi Josh
Hey Chris :blush:
How are you keeping?
Im good thanks, another hot sweaty day in London
how you doing?
Flip tell me about it, my office is filled with printers throwing off heat all day and together with the sun it's been boiling :sweat_smile:
I'm good, my job is pretty laid back and the people are really nice to talk too :blush:
hopefully be back to normal next week tho. Where is it located?
It's located near a town called Portadown which is about 40 minutes outside Belfast near were I live :blush:
Do you live in London?
Oh cool, not too far away. I dont know N.Ireland at all, Only been to belfast once for a wedding
Ah fair enough we're a small country haha :grin:
I know Dublin fairly well tho as I was working there last 2 years. but yea, I'm in London now
I live in surrey which is a 1 hour commute each way ( if i get the right train )
That's a fair commute :sweat_smile:
Blue Zoo office is super central london ( near oxford street /  regents park ) so its fairly easy for everyone to get to
1 hour is very average for London tho. some people its up to 2 hours if they are living with parents
If Bluezoo would only open an office in Belfast that would be far handyer for me haha :grin:
and the closer you get the more expensive :disappointed:
hahaha, it's possible but unlikely :stuck_out_tongue:
Well if I was to go from Stoke to London it would probably take over 2.5 hours :joy:
they are looking into making remote working easier tho. but that could be a while down the line
2.5 hours is on the line of possible
so hows the job going? what kind of projects are you working on?

Well I'm in charge of writing the brief for their new website, I monitor and post on the social media channels, I manage email lists and I create artwork for labels and vectorise existing bitmap graphics :grin:
No Animation unfortunately, although I have made a few .gifs :grin:
oh cool. thats good valuable production experience. comminication is an often overlooked skill in an aniamtion studio and it seems you will get a lot of experience working with different teams
Yeah I really like working in a team environment, when I was at Flickerpix I worked with an Illustrator and an Art Director and it was great :blush:
have you been able to make any progress with your "friend of mine" mood / style research ?
Sea of mine :grin:
haha sorry, sea of mine
And I watched finding Nemo over the weekend (I was very busy so didn't get to really write anything down)
no worries
There's a scene with the sharks that is full of sea mines and a sunken ship which looked really cool.
My Animation will probably be mostly 2D elements but I want to add a lot of layers with parallax to give it depth (pun intended) :grin:
oh cool, thats the kind of thing that would be good to take a screencap of to keep as reference material
Absolutely, I've written it down so I can get it for my mood board.
This could be handy reference too, here are the portfolios for some of the BG artists I have worked with:
<https://melissamalone.art/>

attachments.title: Melissa Malone Portfolio
attachments.text: Melissa Malone is a London-based Art Director for the Animation industry.

text: <http://www.kirstenshiel.com/backgrounds-portfolio>
<https://www.artstation.com/larapickle>

attachments.title: Larisa Bumb
attachments.text: Concept and BG artist, char designer and visual developer!

text: <https://lynnoreilly.wordpress.com/background-art/>

attachments.title: Background Art
attachments.text: Professional Work   Personal Work   College Work

text: Thanks :blush:
Wow they're very talented :heart_eyes:
The first one. Melissa is an art director also
just giving you some reference to the type of portfolio you should be aiming for if you are wanting to aim for art director / BG artist
lots of the production backgrounds are carefully staged to let the acting characters be the focus of the attention
Yeah
I love to draw and paint but I'm not sure if I have what it takes to be a BG artist :grin:
you can be anything with practice :slightly_smiling_face: and this last year of your degree is a good time to focus on something
have you had more thoughts on speciffic roles you would like to be aiming for?
Fair enough.
I haven't thought about it really :persevere:
I guess I'm scared to specialise :sweat_smile:
thats fine. I seemed to have a thought that it might be BGs you wanted to persue. No worries this project will help you figure that out
in general. if you want to work for small studios / companies then being a genaralist is fine ( as long as at least 1 of your skills is good enough to get you hired )
if you want to work for large studios then you need to be good at one specific role ( and then you develop your skillset as you change projects)
Fair enough. Most people I've talked too said they started out as generalists and then specialised when they found their calling
oh really? what kind of studios did they start out at?
I've had a very different experience. I am one of the only people I know that started as a generalist, and then specialised as i got into series work
One of my lecturers went in as a 3D  artist and then over time became a storyboard artist instead :grin:
I think he worked on Pingu
oh interesting. The industry was probably a very different place when they started if they worked on Pingu :stuck_out_tongue:
Oh definitely :sweat_smile:
and in the same vein, what worked for me might not work for you as it was 8 years ago that I graduated.
It's a fast changing industry :persevere:
The UK animation industry is a lot bigger now and you will have more international competition. ( with or without brexit )
Is it harder to get your foot in the door these days? :sweat_smile:
Yeah that's true.
for example, my current team of 70, about 25 are British, 20 are other European and 25 are from USA,Canada,Brazil,Mexico
In some ways yes and in some ways no. Instagram/twitter and the like have changed how artists get found
a few of our team were reached out to because of their work on twitter for example
I guess it's easier to get found but there's also more people to sift through :sweat_smile:
so that can make it easier to get noticed and seem professional before you have your first studio job
the barrier to entry is lower because the access to technology greater. So because of that you have to be better/have a stronger voice than the others to get noticed
Yeah.
I feel so new to this :joy:
the industry is working more on proper internships and training which is good, but generally you wont get hired to do a job unless your showreel/portfolio shows that you can already do that job
Yeah I know that if I got an internship I would really grow as a person but it's so competitive :sweat_smile:
That's why I want this Animation to look very professional and something I can stand behind  and enter into film competitions to get noticed
Its a bit about presentation, a bit about timing, a bit about your networking, a bit about luck
great idea!
So, with that motivation in mind, I'm going to clarify your research assignment.
Using reference images from photography and other artists work create an A4 collage page of research for:
- Environment
Go for it, I need all the help I can get :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
- Colour script
- Pufferfish character
- Mine character
- Background characters
Ok
the reference can be from any style/medium you like. Try to find what 'feels right' not what looks most like what you have in your head
Is a colour script just a general colour palette or something else?
its a colour script over the course of the film
<https://i.pinimg.com/originals/e1/a1/76/e1a176b381d284fd2be23b345fdebe65.jpg>
Ah yeah!
this is one for incredibles
<https://i.pinimg.com/736x/78/29/e1/7829e1381ef6ec77a7b28ff14c56f161.jpg>
So I should just collect scenes from movies/ other mediums for it?
but yea, general colour palette, but as you are likely to want to change the palette over time to emphasise different parts of the story it should not be a 'static' palette
yea, you can do that, but other peoples concept art or nature photography could still be useful also
Ok, wear I studied colour theory and want to use it in my film to help express emotion.
Yeah*
the question you would ask when chosing reference for colour scripts is: "are these colours helping sell the story/emotion/character of this part of the film"
exactly
Yeah :blush:
so for the research stage it is finding colour scripts that you connect with
*finding colour palettes you connect with
Ok
Cool cool, shall we chat same time next week?
Gives me a good excuse to watch movies and browse the internet and art forums :grin:
What day?
haha perfect!
I'd recommend keeping a blog or somethign for this process. It doesnt need to be public, but it is very hand to have one for your own reference or when asking people what they think of it
for example, This is one my team had for a university project: <https://ownlittleworldshort.blogspot.com>

attachments.title: Own Little World
attachments.text: essentially a production diary of the animated short 'Own Little World'

text: Good idea :+1:
chat soon :slightly_smiling_face:
Have a good evening :blush:
